message: My bill to overhaul the appeals process at the VA has now passed both the House and Senate! When the brave men and women of our military return home from their service, they shouldn't have to wait years to receive the benefits they've earned. This bill will help us finally cut down on the backlog.
Great news for those of us who need clean air to live.

Our mission in the Problem Solvers Caucus is simple: getting Congress to stop the blame games and start working on fixing things. I joined Richard Lui on MSNBC over the weekend to talk about our bipartisan ideas for improving the Affordable Care Act.
Next stop: the President’s desk

I've worked with Republicans to pass four laws to help more Americans break into high-paying, high-tech careers. It wouldn't have been possible without our Connecticut STEM Advisory Board. Yesterday we met at Belimo in Danbury to discuss what more we can do to meet the needs of Connecticut's workforce and the small businesses that depend on it.

New Fairfield dad Joel Colindres fled violence in Guatemala to come to the United States 13 years ago. He provides for his two American-born children, ages six and two. He has no criminal record. He's employed, pays taxes, and contributes to his community. And yet he's been ordered to leave the country by the end of next week.  Senator Richard Blumenthal, Chris Murphy, and I are standing with the Colindres family and urging immigration authorities to find a just solution to the Colindreses' case that allows this family to stay together -- and allows this hardworking, tax-paying father and husband - whose life would be at risk back in Guatemala - to continue on his path to American citizenship.

Most of you probably aren't riveted by my frequent updates about the clean-up of contaminated industrial properties... BUT it's actually a really big deal for our state. Every acre of "brownfields" redevelopment creates about 10 jobs, and we have hundreds of acres of these sites throughout Connecticut. I visited one of these properties in Plymouth a few days ago, and my bill to help communities redevelop brownfields sites is making progress in Congress.
I'm holding a town hall meeting in Torrington on Saturday morning. Hope to see you there!

CCARC provides valuable services to folks with intellectual disabilities and their families. It's one of many local organizations that depend on Medicaid to serve the public, which is just one of the reasons the GOP health care bill was so devastating for Connecticut. We need a bipartisan health care plan that actually fixes the problems in our health care system -- one that doesn't take care away from those who most need help just to finance giant tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans.
Live stream of our town hall meeting in Torrington

Racism and the white supremacy movement have no place in our great country.  What's occurring in Virginia is designed to terrorize fellow citizens. We must reject the actions of these violent extremists in the strongest possible terms. I'm praying for the victims of today's horrific events, and for a swift restoration of peace.

Nazism, the KKK, domestic terrorism — these things have no place in our nation, and we have a responsibility to speak out against them. But our responsibility goes beyond that. We need to stand up for the values that unite us as Americans, and then get to work living those values every day.

Joel is a loving, hardworking father who pays his taxes, contributes to his community, and has no criminal record. I am relieved that he will have the opportunity to make his case in court, and can remain with his wife and children while he does so.  While this reprieve is a step toward justice for the Colindres family, their experience is nevertheless a perfect illustration of how broken our immigration system is. Tearing apart the Colindres family won’t make any other American safer or more prosperous. I will continue to push for comprehensive immigration reform that grows our economy, secures our border, keeps families together, and creates an earned path to citizenship.
Steve Bannon never belonged in the White House. Neither does the corrosive racism he brought with him to the job.
Terrible news out of Singapore this morning. Keeping the Sailors of USS John McCain and their families in my thoughts and prayers.

On July 30, 1945, the USS Indianapolis was struck by torpedoes on its return back from Japan, killing nearly 1,200 sailors. On board was Lt. Thomas Michael Conway of Waterbury, who paid the ultimate sacrifice for our country. In his final moments, he comforted those in anguish around him, and administered last rights to those who requested it. Through and through, Lt. Conway was a man of honor, courage, and selflessness.

As a member of Congress, my highest responsibility is to protect and defend the United States of America, and it’s one that I do not take lightly. That’s why it is imperative our service men and women have the backing of the nation when entering into potentially dangerous situations. It is imperative that Congress vote on a new Authorization for Use of Military Force.
When Congress reconvenes in September, tackling the opioid epidemic ought to be a top priority. The longer we wait to address this growing problem, the deadlier—and more expensive—it will become.
Ngoc T Truong Huynh died while honoring his commitment to our country. Pleased to see the Navy recognize his sacrifice.

Yesterday marked a huge step toward our goal to improve the how we, as a country, serve our veterans. Making our nation’s heroes wait upwards of  five years for their rightly earned and deserved benefits is simply unacceptable. Proud to work with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to make this happen, and to begin addressing and resolving the backlog at the VA.

Rep. Esty never forgets a birthday, so today her staff is hacking her Facebook page to wish our boss a wonderful day (and share this adorable photo we found of her). We’re appreciative of all that you do for us, and for all the advice and guidance you are willing to share with us. And more importantly, we’re lucky to have a boss who loves Parks and Recreation and ice cream as much as we do, too. We’re so proud to work for our very own Leslie Knope.

My thoughts and prayers today are with the people of Texas and all affected by Hurricane Harvey. I'm so grateful to the National Guard members, first responders, and civilian heroes who have risked their lives to rescue thousands. I've heard from a number of folks asking what they can do to help - this article has useful information on the best ways to assist our fellow Americans in need.

We shouldn't turn our backs on these young people who are working hard in pursuit of the American dream. They were brought here as kids through no fault of their own and they know no other country. Instead, we should work together to pass comprehensive immigration reform that creates a pathway to citizenship for these folks who contribute to our economy and give back to their communities.

With the right education, training, and resources, we can empower communities to tackle opioid addiction. Everywhere I go in Connecticut, I learn of new families that have been destroyed by this epidemic.This International Overdose Awareness Day, let’s reaffirm our commitment to supporting our friends, families, and neighbors who are at risk and put an end to these senseless deaths.
A cruel decision from which we gain nothing.

Thank you to the hardworking men and women throughout our history who have built our economy from the ground up and advanced the frontiers of workers' rights. In the United States of America, if you work a full week, you should be able to pay your bills, provide for your family, and enjoy a fulfilling retirement. That's the future we look to on Labor Day.
No better way to mark the unofficial end of summer than with a visit to Sweet Claude's for ice cream in Cheshire!

Great profile of young CT journalist Ryan Anastasio. Had the pleasure of being interviewed by him a few months back - he was professional and insightful, and asked tough questions. The youngest member of Connecticut's press corps is also one of the best!

The people that President Trump just turned his back on are hardworking young Americans who contribute to our economy, obey our laws, and give back to their communities. In many cases, they know no other country. For our government to invite these young people to come out of the shadows with the promise of protection only to rip that protection away for political expediency is un-American and indefensibly cruel.  Nobody has ever claimed that DACA is a perfect solution. Temporary protection for hardworking young immigrants is no substitute for the comprehensive reform we need to fix our broken immigration system. But we gain nothing – economically or otherwise – by tossing away those protections without any plan for fixing the underlying problems in our immigration system.  I call on my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to come together and pass comprehensive immigration reform that strengthens our economy and creates an earned path to citizenship. The need for bipartisan action has just become even more urgent.

Moments ago I cosponsored the DREAM Act, which would provide DREAMers with protection from deportation and create a pathway to citizenship for them. Let's end the terrible uncertainty that these hardworking young men and women are dealing with now and pass this bipartisan solution without delay.
Let's drop the politics for a moment. There are thousands of people in Texas who need help rebuilding their lives. Today, Congress and President Trump worked together to make sure they get it.
Today, and every day, we keep in our hearts and prayers all those who were lost and all those who rushed in to save others 16 years on September 11, 2001.
Thanks to the Avon Fire Department for keeping folks safe every day!

Today, I joined my colleagues to support the Manufacturing Extension Partnership. MEP has retained and created jobs, increased sales by $33 million, and retained $77 million in sales in northwest and central Connecticut alone. Throughout the country, it has enabled folks to embark on fulfilling, good-paying manufacturing careers and supported hundreds of small businesses. If the United States wants to keep its seat at the table as the world’s largest economy, it’s not in our interest to gut funding to American manufacturing. Let’s keep MEP and support our manufacturers.

Last week, I joined Joe Courtney in an Armed Services Committee Hearing to discuss ways in which we can improve upon readiness and address the underlying causes of the tragic accidents that occurred overseas this summer. I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress and with Navy leaders to correct these issues as quickly as possible.
Glad to see the House and Senate come together to universally condemn bigotry. Hate has no place in our country. It defies the values our country prides itself on.

Like for so many of our communities across the country, manufacturing is the backbone of Connecticut’s economy. Ensuring we have a strong, highly trained workforce is critical to creating and retaining jobs in Connecticut. That’s why I’m thrilled my amendment to increase funding for the Manufacturing Extension Partnership passed the House today. Every American—no matter their background—deserves the opportunity to compete for good-paying jobs. By investing in the Manufacturing Extension Partnership, we will grow the economy and retain and bring jobs to our communities.

Thank you to the 300 manufacturers who joined Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer and me today for a discussion in Hartford on women in manufacturing. By increasing the number of women and minorities in STEM fields, we will continue to be leaders in innovation.

I am always moved by this image. In 2015, VFW Post 201 in Waterbury, CT laid this wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at the Arlington National Cemetery. On National POW/MIA Recognition Day, we remember those who have made incredible sacrifices to secure our freedom – many of whom never made it home. Today, like every day, I am proudly displaying the POW/MIA flag outside my offices.

Thank you Stephanie Ruhle for hosting Rep. Tom Reed and me. I'm proud to be working with Democrats and Republicans to develop common-sense solutions that keep Americans safe. It's what we were sent to Washington to do.

The newest GOP healthcare bill is more of the same – just another attempt to jam a bad bill through Congress without proper debate or input from both sides. Let’s put the political antics aside and finally have a constructive conversation about how to improve our healthcare system.   While some are trying to score political points, I am working with Republicans and Democrats to find bipartisan solutions that lower costs and expand care. Let’s do this the right way.

Join me this Thursday, September 21, at Waterbury City Hall as we celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month and local Latino and Latina leaders for their contributions to their communities. Looking forward to honoring this year’s nominees and their families.

Last week, I met with leaders of the National Transportation Safety Board to discuss three recent airplane crashes that took place in our district that resulted in 3 deaths. Since that meeting, two additional aviation accidents have taken place. That is five crashes and three deaths too many. We need to ensure that our pilots have the most up to date training and resources to fly safely. As Vice Ranking Member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I am eager to work with experts in the field to prevent similar tragedies in the future.

“It will almost certainly be the most expensive season on record in the United States. That distinction, like most others, currently belongs to 2005, when Katrina and three other major hurricanes caused more than $143.5 billion of damage in the country. But this year, AccuWeather estimated that Hurricanes Harvey and Irma might cost a combined $290 billion: two storms producing double the economic damage of four in 2005.”   These expenses will only climb if we continue to ignore the science behind these worsening storms: climate change is real, it is happening, and the time to act is now. Through strong investments in green energy and technology, and sustainable infrastructure, we can better prepare ourselves and our communities to face these storms.

Terrible news out of Puerto Rico. Now is the time to set politics aside. Congress and President Trump ought to come together to support those affected, and be willing to provide assistance to our brothers and sisters in need in Puerto Rico.
Looking forward to tonight and celebrating outstanding folks from across central and northwestern Connecticut in recognition of Hispanic Heritage Month.
Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month tonight in Waterbury with folks from across central and northwestern Connecticut.
Here's part two of our Hispanic Heritage Month celebration

All too often human trafficking is swept under the rug, assumed to be a crime that happens somewhere else, to someone else.  As I learned when a human trafficking ring was arrested in my hometown, anyone can become a victim of human trafficking. I am proud to work with my friend and colleague Republican Congressman John Katko to address this often-invisible but incredibly harmful crime. Our bipartisan bills will empower the U.S. Department of Transportation to combat human trafficking by giving them the tools they need to stop criminals in their tracks across our nation’s transportation network.
A principled stand by a principled public servant.
Happy to spend National Lobster Day with this pup in Waterbury!

There are millions of Americans in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands who need help rebuilding their lives and communities.  We have watched our friends, families, and loved ones lose their homes, their businesses, their schools, and everything they own. We should not stand idly by while our fellow Americans go without basic necessities. Folks have shared with me their frustrations at being left helpless and unable to reach their loved ones, much less help them. This is unacceptable. We must do better.

Earlier this week, I joined my colleagues in the House in calling for an immediate vote on the DREAM Act. It is time we stop playing politics with people's lives and ensure the necessary protections for those who have come here by no fault of their own, but nonetheless call America home.

We need tax policies that are fair, grow our economy, and support working families. The Republican proposal is not that. The proposal put out today would provide tax cuts for the wealthy at the expense of middle class, working Americans while gutting Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security—programs that are vital to lifting folks out of poverty. I have heard time and time again from businesses and industry leaders across central and northwestern Connecticut the importance and necessity of tax reform and a predictable, stable, and simplified tax code in order to grow jobs, attract innovators, and compete in a global economy. I am calling on my colleagues to come together – Democrats and Republicans - to get this done.

Recently, my colleagues and I sent a letter to House leadership outlining a bipartisan approach to fixing the problems in our health care system. Through common sense health care proposals, we can make better care more affordable and accessible for all. I hope our proposals can be the starting point for the kind of progress the American people deserve, through honesty and transparency.
To all those in Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and Caribbean: We see you. We hear you. We stand with you and we're fighting for you.

We can't operate a 21st century economy on 20th century infrastructure. It's going to take real conversations and ideas to move America forward. This morning I joined my colleagues for a bipartisan meeting at the White House to discuss a path forward on much needed investments in our infrastructure. We need to work across the aisle to modernize our infrastructure and grow the economy.

With each passing day, Congress is failing its duty to the American people, particularly those in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. It has been over a week since Hurricane Maria hit, and folks continue to go without access to basic necessities like food, shelter, and clean water. Congress has, unfathomably, failed to take action.   Tomorrow, funding for programs like the Husky A and B in Connecticut will expire, leaving millions of Americans without reliable sources of aid. Our communities are depending on us to find common-sense, long term solutions that fund vital services for our most vulnerable neighbors instead of threatening drastic cuts.  I am calling on my colleagues to come together to find a bipartisan approach that fully funds programs that keep our country moving forward.
Heartbroken and horrified by the shooting last night in Las Vegas. Awful that such terror should be inflicted on folks enjoying a concert. Our prayers and love are with everyone affected.

If you own guns, and if you believe that the Second Amendment is important to you and this country, but you also believe that each one of us has a right to life and safety, we need you. If you believe that what happened in Las Vegas on October 1st is not OK, help us. Be part of the solution.

Today, my colleagues and I sent a letter to President Trump urging him to enhance federal assistance to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands until both territories become more economically stable. It has been weeks since Hurricane Maria made landfall on Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, yet too many Americans still lack access to clean drinking water, food, and shelter. These delays are unconscionable, and Connecticut’s friends, families, and loved ones in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands deserve more than a federal government that stands by idly as they suffer.
Standing with my colleagues to call for common sense legislation to prevent more senseless gun violence.

Conditions are improving in these areas, but there is still much work to be done. Until Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are back on their feet, we must do all we can to help. Clinton Parker may not see himself as a hero, but when he took action in the middle of a seven-hour police standoff involving a veteran suffering from post-traumatic stress, he became exactly that. He did not do it for glory or praise--he saw someone who needed help, and sprung to action. His courage and selflessness saved--and changed--lives. Clinton earned the National Association of Letter Carriers’ Heroes of the Year Award, and I cannot think of anyone more deserving of this recognition.

The so-called "Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act" has been used to silence the voices of the victims of gun violence and their families for far too long. Under this law, the gun industry receives blanket protection from lawsuits. No other industry in America is shielded this way. This protection is wrong and should be repealed.

Good to join a panel of experts convened by the New Democrat Coalition on the need for investment in our infrastructure and modernization of our roads, rails, bridges, airports, transit, utilities, and water infrastructure. It's these types of projects that will create good jobs for Connecticut workers. We'll do all we can to get action to meet our infrastructure needs.

Today is National Manufacturing Day. In Connecticut, our economy is powered by a rich tradition of manufacturing, represented today by the over 5,000 businesses providing good-paying jobs throughout our state. I was proud to be an original cosponsor of the resolution establishing #MFGDay17, and to join manufacturers in Waterbury and New Britain to learn more about  what their workers are doing to grow our economy.
Always a joy to sit down with the Record Journal. Thanks for having me on your show, Mike!

In the wake of the tragedy in Las Vegas, Americans deserve real answers and real action from Congress to prevent these atrocities from happening again. This past Sunday, I joined Al and Jenn to discuss what I am doing in Congress to make our communities safer.

Planning a trip outside the country? Need a passport? This Saturday, from 12PM to 5PM, the Connecticut Passport Center will be in Canton helping folks renew their passports or file a passport application for the first time. Check out the flyer found here for more details.
Save the date! Please join me this Saturday for a town hall meeting in New Britain. Starts at 10:00 AM, doors open at 9:30 AM. Hope to see you there!

In an hour, I'll be joining my colleagues to introduce the #KeepAmericansSafe Act to protect our families from devices that have turned our schools, theaters, concerts, and far too many other places into killing fields. Our legislation has received the support of law enforcement organizations, veterans, responsible gun owners, and the advocates for victims of gun violence and their families alike. We need to bring everyone to the table to address this epidemic of violence.   Follow along on this page for a livestream of the event.
Introducing the #KeepAmericansSafe Act to protect families from dangerous high-capacity magazines.

ICYMI: On Wednesday, I testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee to emphasize to my colleagues just how serious the opioid crisis is in Connecticut, and what steps we can take to address this raging epidemic. Everywhere I go in Connecticut, I meet people whose families have lost loved ones to drug addiction. Every single community in Connecticut has been touched by this epidemic: it affects families regardless of age, race, gender, or socioeconomic status. These are real people, real families, and real lives that are affected by this crisis. The stakes are too high to limit access and make it harder for folks to get the care and treatment they need to overcome their addiction.
Be sure to tune into our live stream of my New Britain town hall meeting this morning. Starts at 10:00 AM.
We're live here in New Britain at Pulaski Middle School
Our LGBTQIA+ community makes our state better and stronger. Thank you for always speaking up and speaking loudly about how we can make equality a reality for everyone.

At the close of our town hall in New Britain on Saturday, I was approached by MaLisa, who offered me this Wonder Woman notebook.   MaLisa is a real Wonder Woman. She's launched FreeTHEM, an initiative to help kids who have been exposed to the very real challenges of addiction and has served on community boards in Waterbury to help with everything from housing to blight issues to promoting mental health. She's worked closely with our office to improve people's lives in so many ways. We are very lucky to have her.   It's more important than ever that we recognize the wonder women in our country -- women who do so much and ask for little in return. We're proud of you, MaLisa. Keep up the good work.

Started the day today at Avon HS to discuss my work in Congress. The students asked a number of important questions, from how we can encourage people of varied political persuasions to work together in our communities to how changes in technology have influenced the legislative process. These young people give me hope for our future.

Yesterday, I called on Rep. Marino to excuse himself as President Trump’s nominee to head the DEA. This morning, it was announced he did exactly that. Rep. Marino’s aggressive efforts weakened the DEA’s efforts to combat the opioid crisis and made it possible for drugs to make their way into the hands of drug dealers and Americans struggling with addiction.   The Connecticut families I’ve met who lost loved ones to the epidemic of drug addiction plaguing our country deserve better than a DEA chief who, as we now know, was the architect of the effort to cripple the DEA’s ability to confront the opioid crisis. With the state’s medical examiner overwhelmed with autopsies from the countless victims of addiction, we need a reliable federal partner who will put those harmed and their families, not the interests of major pharmaceutical companies, first.

Great to join state and local officials, as well as Xenolith and Dakota Partners, to break ground on the Columbus Commons project in New Britain. When completed, this mixed-use, mixed-income complex will provide a home to families and businesses alike. It's an investment in jobs, as every acre of brownfields redevelopment creates almost 10 jobs. I'm continuing to work to expand funding for the federal brownfields remediation program to boost our local economies.   Congratulations to all those involved in making this project possible.

Over the past ten months, I have received a record number of calls, letters, and emails from folks calling on Congress make our health care system more affordable and accessible to all Americans. Connecticut families agree: our health care system needs to be stabilized, and it needs to be stabilized now. I will continue to call on my House colleagues to come to the table and start talks on how we can reach agreement on health care. There are still real problems in our health care system that we need to fix. It’s time for an approach that’s focused on serving the American people.
Hey Amazon.com, I know the perfect place for your new headquarters… #StillRevolutionary

It’s been a month – a month – since Hurricane Maria made landfall on American soil. One million Puerto Ricans are without running water. Three million are without power, close to 80% of the island’s residents. Homes are still in ruins. Families are calling on their country for help. When I met with FEMA and DoD officials last week, I told them in no uncertain terms that our response to date has been inadequate. I will not stop fighting to ensure that the Americans in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are treated with the human decency they deserve.

Earlier this week, I joined Chris, Brian, and Mike, the owners of the Alvarium Beer Company in New Britain, to discuss the unique situation facing breweries like theirs. Since 2012, there has been a surge of new breweries opening in Connecticut, creating over 4,600 jobs. By working with small business owners like Chris, Brian, and Mike, we can put Connecticut and the rest of the country on the right track to success.

We all know the value of making investments in our infrastructure systems: it creates jobs and puts money back into our economy. But when we talk about these investments, we need to get creative and meet the needs and values of the people. More and more young people do not want to own a car, and with investments in mass transit and ride sharing features, we can attract businesses and families who are looking for an easy commute. By collaborating with state and local governments, as well as the private sector, we can move towards running our 21st century economy on 21st century technology.

STEM education has been one of my priorities since arriving to Congress in 2013, and in an advanced economy like ours—where tomorrow’s jobs are in fields like manufacturing, engineering, and science labs,--it is important we give our children the tools they need to succeed. Though we have made great strides in the STEM industries, women are still significantly underrepresented in these fields or their contributions far too often go unacknowledged. It’s been two years since my bill, the STEM Education Act, became law, and I will continue to focus on finding bipartisan opportunities to strengthen STEM educational opportunities.

It’s 2017. Can we please stop trying to control a woman’s right to reproductive health care and family planning tools? I’m proud to co-sponsor the Protect Access to Birth Control Act, which would effectively negate President Trump’s birth control executive order. Let’s leave family planning to those who know what’s best for them and their lifestyles.
Big bipartisan turnout to celebrate House Transportation & Infrastructure Committee Chairman Bill Shuster - let’s get things done for America!

It's Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and while it's great to wear pink to show support for the cause, we can (and should) do even more. Working with my Democratic and Republican colleagues to fund medical research and protect essential health services so that the 1 in 8 American women who will be diagnosed with breast cancer in their lifetimes receive the care they need.

The current proposal to eliminate the state and local tax (SALT) deduction is bad news for Connecticut. Close to half (41%) of Connecticut filers claim the SALT deduction. We should reform our tax code, but not in a way that hurts workers. Instead of punishing families who deduct their state and local taxes each year, let's focus on encouraging companies to create more jobs right here in Connecticut. I will continue to work with my colleagues to find solutions that work for middle-class families and keep our economy moving in the right direction.

Connecticut has an infrastructure problem: 338 bridges are classified as structurally deficient. It’s not just a Connecticut issue, either: states across the country are struggling to modernize their infrastructure. If we want to move forward and create good-paying American jobs, we need to prioritize repairs and essential new construction. And my colleagues agree with me: that’s why Rep. John J. Duncan, Jr., Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, Congressman Garret Graves, and I created the Congressional Infrastructure Caucus. With this Caucus, we will have an opportunity to call for action on America’s infrastructure needs to update our nation’s outdated roads, bridges, rails, airports, transit, and drinking water. There’s plenty we can do to make proactive, common-sense investments in infrastructure while prioritizing investments in safety, jobs, and Connecticut’s competitiveness.

There have been many ups and downs for this young man and his family in their fight for legal permanent status in the United States. Jason Ramos first approached me about his parents’ case when, while awaiting the opportunity to present their case to a judge, they were scheduled to be deported. The Ramos family had a simple request: hear our case before you deport us. I sent a letter to ICE with Senator Blumenthal and Senator Murphy to ask them to give the family 30 days to have their case heard.   Jason woke up on a Saturday morning two weeks ago to come to my town hall in New Britain and share his optimism for his parents’ future with me. It reminded me of why we need to do all we can to support those who come to this country to work hard and help their families. I am pleased to report that, as of today, the Ramos family has been granted the 30 days requested, and their judge has approved their motion to reopen their case. It’s one hurdle on their road to becoming legal permanent residents, but it was a big one.   Keep fighting, Jason. I’m here for you and for your family.

A bipartisan commitment to the independence of the special counsel is now more important than ever. The American people must know the truth about Russia's attempts to meddle in our elections and subvert our democratic institutions. If we fail to examine this case with objectivity, we risk exposing ourselves to future attacks and further eroding the confidence of the public in our system of government.

I’d like to think Byron Jones's days of interning for my office, and walking (or sprinting, depending on the urgency) the hallways in the Capitol prepared him for his game-winning interception last night.

Visited Casa Boricua in Meriden this morning to discuss our efforts to ensure that the American citizens in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands receive the support they need to recover and rebuild. I've called on the president and my colleagues in Congress to provide funding to help our state and local governments assist families in need while preserving essential services. As Americans, we come together to help each other in times of crisis. It's what we do and who we are.

Here in Connecticut, NASA suppliers are assembling components for our country's deep space program and creating good jobs. Today, I joined officials from the Orion Program, as well as representatives of the American companies providing the hardware necessary to support our missions into deep space, for a briefing on their efforts. As a member of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, I'm committed to supporting missions like Orion, which creates jobs, expands our scientific horizons, and serves as a source of pride for our state and our nation.
Honored to welcome San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulín Cruz to hear about what we still need to do to help our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico.

November 1 isn’t just the first day of the month—it’s also the first day of open enrollment. Make sure you and your family have the information and resources you need from Access Health CT to get (or stay) covered before the December 22 deadline.
Our bill with Rep. Mike Bost to help veterans with disabilities and their families was signed today!
All of hard hittin’ New Britain is proud of George Springer tonight. #MVP #AstrosVsDodgers

This morning during our House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee meeting, I spoke to leading officials from FEMA and other agencies about the federal government’s response to the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. With more than 800,000 folks still without clean water and access to basic supplies and materials, the federal government’s response has been shameful.   When I spoke to folks at Casa Boricua de Meriden earlier this week, folks from Connecticut’s Puerto Rican community shared with me their families’ heartbreaking stories of struggles for survival in Puerto Rico. The fact is, Texas and Florida got immediate relief in ways that Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands did not. All Americans deserve the aid of the federal government wherever they live in this great country.

Let's call the elimination of the deduction for our state and local taxes what it is - a punitive middle-class tax increase. I'm going to work with my Republican and Democratic colleagues to fight it. You deserve tax reform that helps your family and encourages companies to bring jobs back to America, not this.

Our hearts are broken once again with the news from Texas tonight. It’s become increasingly clear that we have two choices: accept this senseless carnage as the new normal in our society, or stand as Americans against the force of the corporate gun lobby to prevent future tragedies. I’m ready to work with anyone, Republican or Democrat, who will help to end the epidemic of gun violence in this country. I hope that responsible gun owners throughout our country will join me to find a better way forward and keep families safe.

Denada Rondos takes care of three children, a home, and the books for her family’s restaurant in my hometown of Cheshire. Her husband Viron works twelve hours a day to put food on the table for the Rondos family. We should be welcoming people like Denada into this country - not throwing them out to face an uncertain future elsewhere.  There are just a few days left until Denada is forced to leave for Albania. I cannot imagine the pain her family is feeling right now. My heart breaks at the thought of her children. I’ve been pushing ICE to grant Denada a stay of removal so that she can make her case in court.   To the Rondos family: Connecticut stands with you. I stand with you. I wish I could promise to keep you together, but I’ll do all I can for you. Cheshire, our state, and this nation are better because you’re with us.

This Veterans Day, we thank the men and women who served our country in uniform not only with our words, but with our deeds. While I’m glad our bipartisan bill to provide a small benefit increase to veterans with disabilities recently became law, there’s so much more we have to do to provide vets with the care and support they’ve earned after serving our country in uniform.   Proud to stand with those who have given so much in defense of our nation.

Joined DEA officials to discuss the latest news on the federal response to the opioid crisis. I'll keep working with both parties to confront this crisis.

If you didn't get a chance to get outside for #NationalTakeAHikeDay, make sure you do someday soon before it gets too cold! I stopped by Roaring Brook Falls last weekend for a sunny and brisk day of hiking.

I certainly think there are more steps we can and should take to keep our families safe, but this is an important step forward.

The students at Western Connecticut State University are conducting research on Lyme disease and pest management. #NetNeutrality is one of the most important issues of our time. What we decide will determine whether or not we care about innovation, job growth, freedom of expression, and core democratic values in our society.   When the FCC last attempted to repeal Net Neutrality rules, 22 million Americans made their voices heard - the largest number of comments the FCC has ever received. Now the Chairman is attempting to roll back Net Neutrality protections once again.   If, as expected, the FCC uses the cover of a holiday to erode the safeguards of a free and open internet, Congress must take swift and immediate action when we return next week.

Convened meetings in Meriden and Torrington with Colonel Conde, the new District Commander for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, New England, and state and local officials to discuss how we can grow our local communities’ economies. There are important projects already happening - from improvements to flood management systems to expanded green spaces and bridge replacements - and we need to help where we can.

News reports indicate that the FCC may well have been flooded with fake anti-#NetNeutrality comments prior to its decision to roll back protections for a free and open internet.   Well, I can tell you that dozens of real, living Connecticut residents have been calling our offices this morning to express their outrage over the FCC's attempt to tamper with their internet access. Please know that I stand with you.  Even on a holiday week, our voices won't be silenced. While I wish we were discussing ways to expand internet access, not limit it, it gives me some hope to see democracy alive and well.

To those calling my offices to ask Congress to #SaveNetNeutrality: please know I support you and I stand with you. I'm sending my staff home a little early to be with their families for the holiday, however, so if you're having trouble getting through and want to make your voice heard, you can always send us an e-mail at the link below. And if you do call, don't fear - we check our messages!

Like mother, like daughter - Sarah and I once again find that we’ve unintentionally worn basically the same thing. Grateful to be with family once again on Thanksgiving - and for those who’ve given up time with family to keep our country and our communities safe.

Just learned that my bipartisan bill to strengthen our country's background check system and prevent dangerous criminals from gaining access to weapons passed the House Judiciary Committee.  I wish I could be happier to deliver this news, but unfortunately, the Committee also voted to advance so-called "concealed carry reciprocity" legislation that would allow anyone to carry concealed weapons virtually anywhere and at any time.   In the coming days, I'll be working with my colleagues like those in the Gun Violence Prevention Task Force to #StopCCR and advance our bill to keep guns out of the hands of abusers and criminals while respecting law-abiding gun owners' rights.

Human trafficking is an appalling, inhumane crime - and it's occurring throughout Connecticut and our country. Proud to let folks know that Congressman John Katko and I were able to get our bipartisan Combating Human Trafficking in Commercial Vehicles Act passed out of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee this morning.   Our bill would provide training to truck drivers - who are often on the front lines when it comes to seeing where and how victims are being moved across the country - to help recognize and report trafficking activity whenever this despicable activity occurs. The bill would also designate a coordinator for anti-human trafficking efforts at the U.S. Department of Transportation.

Returned from the House floor a little while ago, where my bill to revitalize brownfields throughout Connecticut and the country passed with broad bipartisan support. Our region has a long and proud industrial history, but that history has left an unwelcome legacy of brownfields sites.   With this legislation, we can grow our economy and protect our environment: every acre of brownfields cleanup generates close to ten jobs, and every dollar we invest in these projects generates close to $18.   I'm grateful to all of the state and local officials in Connecticut who have been working to renew their communities through brownfields remediation.

Once again, we learn of extremely troubling activity from individuals at the highest levels of our government. As I've said before, Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation must continue to proceed without interference from Congress. We need to learn the full extent of what occurred.

The Affordable Care Act has problems that need to be fixed. I grew up in a town where many young women didn't have access to basic reproductive health care. House Republicans must not try to take America down this dark road. I will forcefully oppose -- and women and men throughout this country will forcefully oppose -- any attempt to rob Americans of health services that they quite literally depend on for survival. #ProtectOurCare

Our country still makes things—bold, innovative, and important things. And, with the right conditions for economic growth, our country will continue to make great things for decades to come. In fact, there is high demand for trained and skilled workers in advanced manufacturing jobs. That’s why I am proud to continue my bipartisan efforts in this next session of Congress to work toward improvements in STEM education and workforce training, which will help folks from all backgrounds break into these high-paying, high-demand fields.

Congress needs to drop its obsession with the politics of the Affordable Care Act and start confronting the massive human cost of robbing millions of Americans of their health insurance.  "I will lose my home and/or I will die," said Gaye Hyre, a breast cancer survivor.

Proud to pass my first two bills of the new Congress today! In spite of the division and partisanship that dominates today's news cycle, there are still those of us working together in a bipartisan way to overcome the challenges the American people are facing.

Thank you, Mr. President.

Yesterday, my Promoting Women in Entrepreneurship Act passed the House of Representatives. You may be wondering, "Why do we need legislation to promote women in the sciences?" The answer is: Because companies have a lot of unfilled jobs, and so many of the women looking for work don't have the training they need to fill them. We can't meet the needs of our economy if women aren't getting the support they need to enter the high-tech fields that are growing right now. Building an inclusive economy isn't just a moral imperative; it's an economic one.

Just in Connecticut, 43,000 children stand to lose their health insurance if the Affordable Care Act is repealed. To my colleagues in Congress, I ask you to look past the politics and imagine yourself as the parent of one of those children. How in good conscience could you vote to deprive millions of Americans of their health care?
A moving story about paying tribute to our lost veterans - and a sobering reminder that our nation MUST do more to repay those who risk their lives in our defense.

Moments ago, 227 of my colleagues voted to set in motion the repeal of the Affordable Care Act without offering a single detail about what a replacement might look like or when it might take effect. Their vote places in grave jeopardy the health insurance of 30 million Americans, the solvency of rural hospitals, and the survival of over 2.6 million jobs that economists estimate will go away if the Affordable Care Act is repealed.  This political crusade to unravel our nation's health care system is a national disgrace. But this fight isn't even close to over. I will continue to stand up for affordable, accessible health care for every single American.

Today let's do more than reflect on the towering legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Let's commit to that legacy. Let's act on it. Let's do good in its name. Let's follow Dr. King's example and dedicate ourselves to social and economic justice.

Huge crowd in Hartford today with a loud and clear message for Congress: Don't repeal the Affordable Care Act, especially if we have no idea what will replace it.  This is my constituent, Jonathan, from Meriden: "My life is on the line, and they're making it up as they go along. I can't accept that." Jonathan speaks for millions.  The health coverage of 30 million Americans is too important to make it up as we go along.  The 2.6 million jobs that will disappear if the ACA is repealed with no replacement are too important to make it up as we go along.  The families who depend on ACA-funded programs to get the treatment they need to recover from opioid addiction are too important to make it up as we go along.  The rural hospitals throughout the country kept afloat by the ACA are too important to make it up as we go along.  For all the talk of a "replacement plan," seven years after the passage of the ACA, Speaker Ryan and his colleagues haven't named even the slightest details of what a new plan might include, much less who would be covered by it. Let's be real here: there is no plan. Repeal IS the only plan we've heard after seven years. The American people's health care matters way too much play games with in the name of politics.

Betsy DeVos's baffling response to Senator Chris Murphy's question about keeping kids safe from gun violence at school suggests this isn't an issue she's given any serious thought. Building up Connecticut's advanced manufacturing sector is one of the most important things we can do to grow our state's economy. The company's EVP Mike Greenwald told me that they see huge potential in Connecticut's students and workforce. It’s time for our nation to have a frank and compassionate conversation about immigration reform, no matter how tough this issue is. There are real people and real families on the line here, and it was so productive to hear firsthand what folks are concerned about.  It would be dishonest for me to say that I know for sure what's going to happen next, but I do know that I will not stop fighting for the hardworking families who live in Connecticut's 5th District.

So grateful to everyone who joined me in Waterbury for a discussion about the future of American health care. Some important takeaways:  - Repealing the Affordable Care Act without a replacement helps nobody - not the 32 million people who will lose insurance, not the millions of others who will see their premiums double.  - Repealing the ACA will be really tough on our local hospitals, and on folks who rely on mental health services.  - The ACA has flaws that need to be fixed, such as broadening the network of primary care providers. Being opposed to repealing the law absolutely should not mean being opposed to making improvements that will help more people get quality health care.  - Donald Trump and congressional Republicans haven't told the public any details about what kind of system might "replace" the ACA. Two hours ago, Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th President of the United States.  My mission as the representative for the people of central and northwest Connecticut is to find solutions to the problems our families are facing – all of our families. I believe in that mission, and I’m more committed to it than ever. When fulfilling that mission means working with President Trump, I will work with him. When fulfilling that mission means opposing President Trump, I will be as loud and forceful as I need to be in defense of our American values.   President Trump promised today that he would work to find common solutions to the problems facing our nation. For the good of the country, the world, and the people of Connecticut’s Fifth District, I sincerely hope his actions as President reflect that commitment.  Let today be the day that President Trump swears off Twitter feuds and personal attacks and starts reaching out to Americans from all walks of life in search of common ground. Let today be the day that President Trump drops his reckless assault on America’s intelligence agencies and starts standing up for America’s security and our place as the leader of the free world. Let today be the day that President Trump leads his Republican Party away from the shameful political crusade against Americans’ health coverage and begins reaching across the aisle on a real strategy to improve care for all Americans.   Let today be the day President Trump starts following through on his pledge to work together to revitalize our nation’s infrastructure, improve care for our nation’s veterans, and promote American manufacturing. If he is truly committed to tackling these and other problems in a bipartisan way, then I stand ready to work with him. There is so much good and important work that the American people are counting on all their elected officials to do together. It is time for us to put country first.
Beautiful day for a march! Hundreds of thousands of folks have come to D.C. to stand up for their rights. I have so much faith in American democracy. This is why – this is what democracy looks like.

44 years ago, Roe v. Wade made a woman's right to make her own decisions about her reproductive health the law of the land. Today, many of us are worried that right is in peril. It's one of the reasons millions of us took to the streets yesterday to make our voice heard. Congress and our new President would be wise to take note.  With my voice and vote, I will continue to stand up for reproductive freedom and access to quality care for every American. When it comes to women's bodies, politicians don't get to call the shots.

Sat down with 14-year-old Connecticut student Ryan Anastasio for a truly excellent interview. Ryan's a real pro. His questions led to a great discussion about growing our state's economy, President Trump's cabinet selections, and the importance of bipartisanship in today's divisive climate.  Note for my colleagues: If you set up an interview with Ryan, come prepared!

Just two days after millions of women and men across the world marched for gender equality, President Trump proved he wasn't paying attention to their message. This afternoon he reinstated the archaic "Global Gag Rule," which prohibits U.S. foreign aid abroad to health providers who provide women with complete medical information and guidance about their reproductive options.  This decision goes beyond health care. It will reverse some of the economic, social, and political gains women around the world have made due to increased access to education surrounding family planning resources. And -- if past is prologue -- it will make abortion both more frequent and less safe.  In the face of injustice, we cannot be silent. I will continue to join millions of my fellow human beings around the world in standing up for the lives and freedoms of every person.

Exciting news! I was just elected to the leadership of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee! I can't wait to partner with Democrats and Republicans on a bold plan to create good-paying jobs in Connecticut and across the country -- and to make America's transportation systems the envy of the world.

Nothing President Trump did today will make us safer, grow our economy, or fix our broken immigration system. These actions are political gimmicks that will serve only to harass and tear apart law-abiding families. The President is attempting to initiate one of the worst crackdowns on immigrant families in American history – going even beyond dark chapters in our past when political leaders punished immigrants for their own failure to find solutions to our country’s challenges. I won’t sit by quietly and allow that to happen.  The President’s threat to strip funds from cities whose local police don’t waste their own money locking up law-abiding immigrant families will make communities throughout Connecticut less safe. The President’s proposed border wall – which countless immigration experts have said won’t actually help our border security – will nevertheless be constructed at the expense of U.S. taxpayers. The President’s plan to detain more law-abiding immigrant families in inhumane conditions not only promises to be a human-rights disaster; it will also waste law-enforcement resources that could be used to fight crime and save lives.  I’m proud to represent many hardworking immigrant families in central and northwest Connecticut. I stand with them in solidarity, and I will do everything I can to ensure their rights, freedoms, and futures are protected.  For Connecticut immigrant families, my staff and I created a Know Your Rights resource guide. You can find it here: https://esty.house.gov/what-are-my-rights

Earlier today, I launched part one of a two-day listening tour, aimed at listening to folks about their concerns and ideas in regards to how to improve transportation and infrastructure across central and northwestern Connecticut. In both Waterbury and Danbury, I heard time and time again the importance of building bridges (pun intended) between different sectors of government, businesses, and communities to ensure Connecticut creates an inclusive plan that will not only modernize our state’s current transportation infrastructure, but ensure we meet the other demands that go along with it. Connecticut will play a key role in the federal government’s transportation’s plans moving forward—let’s make sure we advocate for what we deserve.

Don't ever doubt that your voice matters. It has never mattered more.

Thinking tonight about my great-great-grandmother, Trientje Poppen, the woman in the middle of the third row. This photo was taken on July 4, 1911 (or maybe 1912), more than 60 years after the family emigrated from Holland. Trientje is remembered in my family as the one who tirelessly pulled a plow then they couldn't afford oxen.  If our nation hadn't welcomed her, I wouldn't be here today. It breaks my heart to think of all the talent, all the incredible families and kids, that our government will be turning its back on if we don't reverse President Trump's executive order.

Yesterday I joined with over 170 of my colleagues to introduce a bill that would overturn President Trump's cruel and inhumane executive order. To families in CT and across the country whose lives are now in turmoil because of this ban, I want you to know: I stand with you, and our work together is only just beginning.

I'm honored that Imam Hamid Malik, of the Baitul Aman Mosque in Meriden, will be my guest tomorrow at this year's National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C. Imam Malik comes to D.C with a message of peace and fellowship that we need today more than ever.  A little over a year ago, a person motivated by Islamophobia fired gunshots into the Baitul Aman Mosque. Thankfully, no one was injured, and what happened next is an incredible story of forgiveness and compassion. You can read about it here.  I'm so proud to represent this community and to work with amazing community leaders like Imam Malik.

I'm so honored that Imam Hamid Malik, the Regional Imam for the  Baitul Aman Mosque in Meriden, joined me as my guest at this morning's National Prayer Breakfast. Together, Imam Malik and I sent out this statement afterward:  Today’s National Prayer Breakfast, attended by people of all faiths and backgrounds, is an occasion to look past our differences and celebrate all that unites us as human beings. Now more than ever, our country must stay true to the values that have defined us – justice, empathy, and compassion. We see from the shooting at our Mosque in Meriden and the recent one in Quebec that words matter and can have deadly and lethal consequences.  We are deeply concerned with the implications of the President’s recent executive orders. Targeting all Muslims in select Muslim-majority countries amounts to a religious test for entry into the United States. Fashioning policy around a single community or faith is not consistent with American values. American Muslims must play – and have played – a central role in combating extremism in all its forms. To drive a wedge between Muslims and the rest of America is not only immoral and unjust; it risks alienating families and communities across the country that play an integral role in our nation’s fight against terrorism.  Let us work together on a path forward that is fair and balanced, that keeps our nation safe, and that stays true to our American values. Let us work together to enrich ourselves and each other through education, which empowers us to embrace both our extraordinary diversity and our common humanity. Building communities centered on empathy, compassion, and respect requires more than talking about those values; it requires living those values, day in and day out, even when it’s not easy.

We need tax policies that work for working families, keep kids out of poverty, and enable every American to get the education they need unlock their potential. Today, I helped introduce two bills that would put us on the right track.

Black History Month isn't just about celebrating the legends of the civil rights movement. It's about honoring the heroes and role models right here at home, who have enriched our communities through acts of courage and kindness.

Since I serve in the House, I don’t get a vote on the nomination of Betsy DeVos for Secretary of Education. But as an American, a representative, and a former PTA mom, I am using my voice to say that I emphatically oppose her nomination. I urge all my Senate colleagues to stand up for our nation’s kids tomorrow by voting NO on Betsy DeVos.

Right now, the House Science Committee is holding a hearing entitled "Make EPA Great Again." That's ironic for many reasons, not least because some of my Republican colleagues are rallying behind a new bill to abolish the EPA altogether.  Our committee should be embracing science to solve the longstanding economic and environmental problems facing the American people - issues like climate change, air pollution, contamination of our waterways. But sadly, much of the hearing has been devoted to suppressing and discrediting the work of peer-reviewed scientists.  If "Make EPA Great Again" means "Turn EPA over to corporations that have made pollution their business model," then count me out. #DefendEPA #DefendScience #DefendFacts

Proudly renewing my membership in the LGBT Equality Caucus! This issue is deeply personal for my family and me. We've made incredible progress in recent years, and I'm committed not just to protecting that progress but to building on it. No matter who you are or who you love, you deserve freedom, dignity, and equality under the law.

I was named to the Veterans' Affairs Committee today! I'm really, really excited about this. It's a fantastic opportunity to work across the aisle on behalf of those who bravely served our nation in uniform — and I intend to make the most of it.
She was warned. She was given an explanation. Nevertheless, #shepersisted.

This week’s Constituent Corner: Jahvon John of Watertown came to the United States from Barbuda with his father — a citizen — when he was eight months old. Jahvon spent his whole life believing he was a U.S. citizen. It’s the only country he’s ever known to be home. So, you can imagine his surprise when he turned 16, went to apply for driver’s license, and found out that the proper paperwork to ensure he was a citizen was not filed. Jahvon spent five years trying to navigate the bureaucracy on his own before he called my office. With our help, in a matter of months, Jahvon became a naturalized citizen, and was able to finally get his driver’s license and a social security card.  While I’m proud to be a part of Jahvon’s story in becoming a citizen, it’s a reminder that our immigration system creates unnecessary barriers for even hardworking, lifelong Americans like Jahvon. That’s just one reason why we should be focused on comprehensive immigration reform that focuses on keeping families together and attracting the best and brightest to the United States, rather than demonizing families who seek to make their home here.

The separation of powers at work. This is why we have — and cherish — an independent judiciary. There's a long road ahead, but this court ruling is a resounding victory for our security, our humanity, and our democracy.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act wouldn't just rob 32 million Americans of their health coverage. It would damage every element of our health care system. We would all feel the effects. Read more about how repealing the law would:  - cause prescription drug prices to skyrocket for seniors (https://tinyurl.com/ACAretirees)  - threaten the survival of rural hospitals (https://tinyurl.com/ACAhospitalcosts)  - force community health centers to shut their doors (https://tinyurl.com/ACAcommunityhealth)  - undermine our efforts to combat opioid addiction (https://tinyurl.com/ACAopioidaddiction)  - kill thousands of jobs (https://tinyurl.com/ACAjobsurvival)  - harm people who live with HIV (https://tinyurl.com/ACAforHIV)  We cannot allow our health care system to be thrown into chaos just to satisfy a political crusade.

If General Flynn set out to undermine our sanctions against Russia, as these reports suggest, then his actions quite plainly failed to serve the interests of our nation's security. As he is the White House's National Security Adviser, that is stunning. We can't - and won't - let this issue drop. Further investigation is urgently needed, and there should be bipartisan support for it.

I'm calling for an independent investigation to determine the full scope of the White House’s ties to and communications with Russia. This investigation must determine whether General Flynn acted with the approval of other officials in the administration. It must also determine which, if any, officials were aware of General Flynn’s activities – but declined to act on them until a public outcry forced them to.  Russia is an oppressive, autocratic regime that is engaged in an ongoing campaign to weaken our nation and undermine our democracy. The American people need confidence that the White House takes this threat seriously and is working to keep our nation safe from it.

It's good to see that, even in this era of unprecedented partisanship, we can come together to support our nation's brave veterans. Last night, we passed three bipartisan bills to encourage businesses to train and hire more veterans and to help congressional offices assist military families with their benefits claims more effectively. I'm looking forward to building on this work in my new role on the Veterans' Affairs Committee.
Escalating Russian aggression is a serious national security matter. We need to be serious about responding to it. That's the "real story."

Very honored that I will now be serving as lead Democrat on the House Subcommittee that oversees veterans' benefits. I'm ready and eager to partner with my colleagues, Democrats and Republicans, to help all veterans and military families get the support and care they deserve - with less red tape and fewer delays.  At our first subcommittee hearing, I talked about how important it is to make the claims process for veterans function better, with more accountability and personalized service.

To transgender folks around this country who feel alone or under attack: I want you to know that I stand with you.  This movement is about basic dignity, respect, and equality for every American. It's about the freedom to live as who you are. These are fundamental American values, and we will defend them. #EveryoneWelcome

Three years ago at VFW Post 201 in Waterbury, I met with families whose loved ones had died in the line of duty to our country. We talked about the need to do more to honor those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in defense of our freedom.  Joe Nolan, a veteran himself who lost his son, Sgt. Joseph Nolan, in Iraq in 2004, came to the meeting with an idea: a postage stamp to honor the memory of all fallen heroes of America's wars and their surviving families.  Today, I was proud to reintroduce the Support Families of Fallen Service Members Act in the House. Our bipartisan bill directs the U.S. Postal Service to issue a "Families of Fallen Heroes" postage stamp, the proceeds of which will help fund programs that provide direct assistance to the families of fallen service members at a time when they most need support.

The House quietly voted yesterday to continue waging war against Planned Parenthood. If the measure that passed becomes law, it won't do anything to reduce the rate of abortions. What it will do is make it harder for women throughout the country to access vital services like pap tests, HIV screenings, and breast exams.  Last month, millions of us marched in the streets in defense of our rights and our access to health care. It won't be the last time. We're in this for the long haul.

When my colleagues talk about repealing the Affordable Care Act, my mind jumps to my constituent Susie Clayton, a breast cancer survivor who could lose her house if the law is repealed. Please take a minute to listen to - and share - Susie's story.

Climate change is real, it is happening, and the longer we wait, the harder it will be to contain the damage. President Trump’s planned executive orders would sacrifice our quality of life today and the wellbeing of our planet tomorrow for corporate giveaways. The cost is not just our environment – it’s our economy. Our public lands and waterways sustain an outdoor recreation industry that in turn sustains thousands of jobs.

Antisemitism has no place in America, and we will never allow it to claim one. The threats and acts of vandalism targeting Jewish community centers and cemeteries are despicable and fundamentally un-American, and they must end. We must take every step to identify and prosecute the cowardly individuals behind these crimes.  We are a nation that embraces religious freedom. We will not be intimidated into abandoning our values. Not now, not ever.

Right now, President Trump’s pledge to stand by LGBTQ Americans looks like empty words. His administration announced today it will abandon transgender kids around the country who are just looking to attend school in peace without suffering through harassment and discrimination. The cruel decision to rescind guidance affirming the rights of transgender students sends a shameful message to some of the most vulnerable kids in the country that their government doesn’t care about their civil rights or their safety.  Last week, when President Trump made his first move to undermine the rights of transgender students, I recorded a message to transgender Americans to say: I’m with you. Today I want to reiterate that message. There are millions of us who stand with you, today and every day. We will never stop working to protect your freedom to live as who you are, with the dignity and respect that every human being deserves. Together, we will move forward.

I am thrilled to be recognized with a 100% National Environmental Score for my voting record by the League of Conservation Voters. We have an economic, social, and moral responsibility to protect and preserve our environment. Even though the job's gotten tougher, I will keep working hard for clean air and water, public lands, climate science, and preserving wildlife.

America’s aging infrastructure is a major economic, environmental, and safety concern for folks across the country. In fact, by 2020, 70 percent of the dams in the United States will be more than 50 years old. Without the proper investment in structures like our dam system, the costs to replace these structures will only increase—as will the risk for damage to them as well. That's why we need a bold plan to revitalize our infrastructure and make it the best in the world.

I've received hundreds of calls and emails from constituents urging me to oppose a bill to terminate the EPA.  So let me be very clear: This is a terrible bill. I oppose it. I'll do everything I can to ensure we have a functional EPA, which is vital to our economy and our children's future.  Thank you for all the calls. Stay engaged! Make your voice heard!

Honored to be joined by Waterbury's Chief of Police, Vernon Riddick, as my guest for President Trump's address tonight. At a press conference with law enforcement officers from around the country to say to the President: If we are serious about protecting law enforcement, we need to take action to prevent gun violence.
My op-ed in today's News-Times: Let's stop obsessing over the politics of repealing the Affordable Care Act and start talking about the staggering human stakes.

My bills to help women break into science and tech fields were signed into law a few minutes ago! These bills -- the Promoting Women in Entrepreneurship Act and the Inspire Women Act -- will expand entrepreneurial training for women, support education programs that ready girls for careers in aerospace, and encourage women to start their own small businesses.  Even with so many tough fights ahead, we will still have victories to celebrate. Every little girl in this country deserves the very same opportunities to achieve her dreams that boys have — and that's a future I will never stop fighting for.

The values President Trump talked about in his speech tonight – ideas like standing up to special interests, securing our national defense, and expanding economic opportunity – were totally at odds with the divisive and damaging policies he has pursued and the appointments he has made since taking office. But the words tonight must be understood in the context of the actions the President has taken in the last five weeks and will be judged by the actions he takes going forward.

The omissions in Attorney General Sessions' testimony before Congress are extremely concerning. He must recuse himself from this investigation so that the public can be assured of its integrity.

No one's allowed to read it, there won't be a hearing on it before it goes to mark-up, and no analyses of its economic impact have been conducted.  Speaker Paul Ryan, when legislation that affects people's lives gets released to the public, that's not a "leak." That's transparency.
Our veterans — and their families — have made huge sacrifices on behalf of our nation. They need and have earned a cost-of-living increase. Let's make sure they get one.
