Just like the initial executive order that was halted by the courts, today’s action is a dangerous strategic blunder that weakens our nation while strengthening our enemies. If it is not swiftly overturned, this executive order will undermine our counterterrorism efforts, diminish our standing in the world, and put the lives of our troops at risk.  And just like the first order, today’s action is immoral, inhumane, and fundamentally un-American. It deliberately targets people of a single faith, Islam, for discrimination and hostility. It reinforces Islamophobic sentiments at a time when religious communities throughout the country are being targeted by violence. It will leave vulnerable children and families who are fleeing terror with nowhere to go for safety.  Congress cannot sit idly by while the President’s executive orders jeopardize American lives. Our national security is on the line. It’s time for congressional leaders to stop being silent and start doing their jobs.

Access to health care is a right. While the Affordable Care Act has helped a lot of Americans gain access to quality, affordable health coverage, I have always said it is not perfect and needs to be improved.  But the bill released by Republican leaders is not a serious proposal to help Americans get better health care or save money. It plainly does neither. Under this bill, millions of families will lose their health coverage and see it replaced with nothing. Millions of others will pay more for less: higher costs, worse coverage. Meanwhile, health care executives making more than $500,000 get a tax cut.

#DayWithoutAWoman is about standing up together for a brighter future for all of our children and all of our daughters. Whether you're striking today – or whether you just can't miss a day at work or are busy looking after family – your voice matters and you deserve to be heard. #SheMeansBusiness

Earlier today, the House Veterans' Committee advanced a bill that would make it much harder for the VA to prevent a veteran who is at risk of harming themselves from purchasing a gun. This bill puts at risk the very veterans who need help the most. With more than 20 veterans dying by suicide per day - the vast majority by firearm - the bill makes it easier, not harder, for those veterans in crisis to get access to a gun.  You can watch my remarks in committee opposing this bill below, and I stand ready to oppose it on the House floor. There are things we can and should do to reduce veteran suicides while fully respecting the Second Amendment. We should be working together to end these tragedies instead of jamming through partisan legislation to undermine the safeguards that are already in place.

The ACA is not perfect. It has flaws that we need to fix. The problem is that this proposal fixes none of them. "[T]he bill is almost certain to reduce overall coverage, result in deductibles increasing, and will phase out Obamacare's Medicaid expansion."  We should be working in a bipartisan way to repair the parts of the ACA that aren't working. We should, for instance, repeal the Cadillac Tax -- which I've voted to do but which the GOP proposal leaves in place. And we should take steps to reduce drug prices by going after price gouging and ensuring companies are fairly compensated for research and development.  What we can't do is pass a bill that solves none of these problems just to say we passed a bill.

This devastating report on our deteriorating roads, bridges, rail, airports, aviation, transit, wastewater systems, and drinking water makes clear the desperate need for action by Congress and the President. The time is now for a bold, comprehensive, bipartisan plan to move American infrastructure into the 21st century.

Last year, Congress passed landmark legislation to help folks living with addiction and mental illness get the care they need. This health care proposal would take us backward by ripping away coverage for mental health and addiction treatment. We should be building on the progress we've made, not pursuing a political crusade on the backs of families in crisis.

Very glad we were able to assist Michelle, a Farmington resident, after her tax refund was mysteriously $500 lower than it should have been. There is no need for folks like Michelle to navigate through federal agencies alone. My staff and I can help.

The GOP health care bill would saddle Jonathan Miller with thousands of dollars in new costs. For Jonathan, who lives with cystic fibrosis, that means having to pick and choose among the medications that help him stay healthy.
Congressman Steve King, you could not be more wrong. America was proudly built by "babies" born here and all over the world.

The CBO report makes it very plain: passing this bill will harm millions of Americans. It's time for Congress to scrap this ill-considered proposal and get to work on a bipartisan plan to lower premiums, improve access to quality care, and lower the cost of prescription drugs.

Families from across Connecticut and around the world travel to the Farmington River for the recreational opportunities it offers. Today we introduced legislation to preserve this economic and environmental treasure for future generations.

Great meeting today with the U.S. Secretary of Veterans Affairs, David Shulkin. We had a productive discussion about how we can work together to help veterans in mental health crisis and address the tragic epidemic of veteran suicide. Also talked about how we can enhance the Million Veteran Program, a research initiative to help us treat, cure, and prevent military-related illnesses.
Democracy is resilient.

A budget is a statement of our values. If Congress enacts President Trump's budget proposal, the message sent to the American people will be that Congress simply doesn’t value the wellbeing of the families we were elected to serve.  This budget would devastate Connecticut’s economy. It would gut programs that help Americans break into high-tech, high-paying careers. Transportation TIGER grants that have helped our communities repair highways, bridges, and transit systems would be wiped out. Innovation and clean-energy grants that have helped companies across Connecticut create jobs would be gone.  The budget would leave low-income families and seniors in Connecticut quite literally out in the cold, without access to critical housing, heating, nutrition, or employment assistance. It would eliminate programs that protect the air we breathe, the water we drink, and the planet we leave for our children.  The budget would also make our nation less safe. The drastic cuts to the State Department would weaken our ability to prevent conflicts and crises that endanger American security and damage our standing in the world.  We should be working together, Democrats and Republicans, on a bipartisan budget that will strengthen working families, promote job creation, and revitalize our nation’s infrastructure. We should be investing in all elements of our national defense – both military power and the diplomatic institutions that help us avoid military conflict. I call on my colleagues to reject President Trump’s proposal and start from scratch on a budget that reflects our values as Americans.

Every day in this country, more than 20 veterans commit suicide, and the vast majority use a gun. And yet today, the House advanced a bill, H.R. 1181, that would make it easier, not harder, for veterans in mental health crisis to buy guns. I led the opposition to this misguided bill on the House floor today. We need thoughtful, bipartisan action to address the crisis that our most vulnerable veterans are facing. H.R. 1181 would put more veterans - and their families - in harm's way.

Great conversation with Ali Velshi on MSNBC about why we need an independent investigation into the Trump campaign's ties to Russian officials, and about why we cannot give up on bipartisanship no matter how challenging our political climate gets.

If you're planning a trip to D.C., friendly reminder that my staff and I can arrange tours of the Capitol and other historic buildings! We were happy to help folks from the Community Association for Community Action in New Britain see the old Senate and Supreme Court chamber and other historic parts of the Capitol this week. Cleaning up contaminated "Brownfields" properties isn't just an environmental issue; it can spur growth in local economies throughout Connecticut. President Trump's budget would strip our cities and towns of federal funding they need to convert abandoned, hazardous sites into economic assets. In the coming days, I'll be introducing legislation - with a Republican colleague - to make sure that doesn't happen. More info here.

Director Comey’s testimony today makes clearer than ever the need for a nonpartisan, independent investigation into Russia's efforts to influence our election. The American people deserve to know the full scope of Russia’s activities, including who within the United States knew about them or participated in them.  Director Comey also confirmed today that President Trump’s wiretapping claim is wholly unsubstantiated. President Trump’s baseless accusation of criminal activity by his predecessor is beneath the dignity of the Presidency. These repeated, unfounded assertions will do irreparable harm to President Trump’s credibility. He needs to acknowledge to the public that his claim was false.

When my daughter Sarah was 15, she overheard me talking about how I didn't like what was happening on our town council. She said, “Mom, you always told us if you saw a problem and you can do something about it, to step up and do it yourself. If you want to run for town council, I’ll run your campaign. But if you don’t want to run, you don’t get to complain about it anymore.”  It was one of those moments where I either had to live my words or eat them, and I wasn’t prepared to eat them in front of all three of my kids right then and there.

When my niece Julie returned from Kabul with hearing loss sustained from IEDs, our family learned firsthand about the unique barriers to care facing the women who served this country. There are more than 2 million woman veterans in the U.S., and we need to make sure the VA is equipped to serve them. Today, a bipartisan group of us introduced the Deborah Sampson Act, which will help end gender disparities at the VA and ensure all women who put themselves in harm's way in defense of our freedom receive the high-quality care they deserve.

Joe Biden came to the Capitol today and, as usual, cut right through the malarkey. Improving the health care system is not about politics. It's about real families, real parents who deserve the security of knowing that if their child gets sick, they'll have access to the care they need to get better.

Many veterans who were deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan are suffering serious health consequences from exposure to burn pits. These brave men and women need and deserve more help than they are getting. We cannot repeat our shameful inaction after the Vietnam War, when the government failed to acknowledge the terrible toll of Agent Orange on the heroes who served and sacrificed for our country.
There are real problems in our health care system that we must solve. TrumpCare solves none of them. It asks working families to pay more and get less. Here's why I'm voting No.

Enough is enough. We are not going to solve the problems in our health care system with one party negotiating against itself. We need serious, bipartisan solutions to lower premiums, expand access to care, and reduce drug costs. I'm ready and eager to get started. Let's drop the political crusade and take real action.

Last night, the GOP health care bill was quietly changed to gut the ACA's protections for folks with preexisting conditions. That's not progress. It's a betrayal of President Trump's campaign promise and, more urgently, a recipe for disaster for families throughout the country.

The GOP health care bill has been pulled from consideration due to lack of support. Thank you to all who called and emailed to make sure Congress knew how this bill would harm you and your families. Your time and energy made an enormous difference.  There are problems in our health care system that we should be working together to fix. I'm ready and eager to work with Republicans and Democrats on that important mission.

The bill would let internet service providers sell data about your internet browsing and app activity to advertisers without your permission.   When you sign up for internet service, you're not signing up to have your web history sold to the highest bidder. Please know that I will be voting NO.

Instead of confronting the economic and environmental realities of air pollution, President Trump's executive order would have us believe those realities don't exist. But I plan to keep fighting harder than ever for policies that spur economic growth AND protect our environment.

The federal Brownfields program helps communities throughout CT transform contaminated, abandoned properties into economic assets that create jobs. But its funding is in jeopardy. Yesterday, I introduced a bipartisan bill with Congressman John Katko to ensure future funding for the Brownfields program. Our bill also improves the program based on feedback from local leaders like Mayor Neil O'Leary and Mayor Kevin Scarpati.

I've heard loud and clear from my constituents that they don't want agenda-driven pseudoscience funded by the fossil fuel industry determining the EPA's actions on climate change and air pollution. And yet today the House took up a bill to limit the EPA's ability to use the findings of peer-reviewed public health studies in their work, which would force the agency to rely more on industry-funded "research." I spoke on the House floor about what this bill would mean for Connecticut.

I've talked with so many Connecticut veterans and family caregivers of World War II, Korea, Vietnam and other eras who aren't getting the support they need. Part of the problem is that a vital VA program to assist family caregivers is open only to post-9/11 veterans and families. My bill with Congressman Ryan Costello would open the Caregivers program to veterans and families of all service eras.
Heroes not just today, but every day. #WelcomeHomeVietnamVeteransDay

Thrilled to report that three students from our congressional district whom I nominated for admission have been accepted into the United States Military Academy at West Point. George, Joseph, and Ryan will make Connecticut and our nation proud!
And they're off! A little rain isn't going to stop these people. Honored to be here this morning for the Sandy Hook 5K, sharing this special morning with this amazing community.

It was an honor to help welcome the Polish Ambassador to New Britain on Friday. There is no place better suited to host the first Polish Consulate of Connecticut!

More than 20 veterans per day take their own lives in this country. Stopping the tragic deaths of these heroes needs to be a federal budget priority. The loss of one veteran to suicide is one too many.
I'm marking #EqualPayDay by joining with fearless champion for economic justice Rosa DeLauro to introduce the Paycheck Fairness Act. It's time for equal pay for equal work.

Today I joined with my friend John Larson to introduce a bill that keeps Social Security solvent for our kids and grandkids while strengthening benefits. There are more than 600,000 people in Connecticut who depend on Social Security to pay their bills. The Social Security 2100 Act ensures their benefits keep pace with the cost of living.
Every single child in this country deserves clean, safe drinking water. I'm fighting to make our government live up to its commitment to provide it.

In response to a hateful protest against the Muslim faith occurring in Waterbury today, over 100 members of our community stood at City Hall in solidarity with their Muslim friends and neighbors. I couldn't be there, but I sent this statement to be read aloud on my behalf, and I wanted to share it with all of you:  "Hate has no place here in Waterbury, in Connecticut, or in the United States. People who incite violence against religious groups in the name of America are not protecting our great country. They are defaming it. They are damaging it. Freedom of religion is fundamental to who we are as Americans, and I am proud to use my First Amendment rights to join all of you in standing up for that principle and to reject hate and discrimination in all their forms.   "Waterbury is home to people of all faiths and backgrounds. It makes our community a wonderful place to live. People of the Muslim faith are our family members, our friends, and our neighbors. They are our teachers, doctors, colleagues, small business owners, and civic leaders. Throughout history, extremists of all types have committed acts of terror to instill fear and to tempt us into abandoning our values. How we respond is a defining question for us. Do we allow ourselves to be baited into hate and bigotry? Are we a community that gives into fear and allows our neighbors to be terrorized and vilified? Or will we stand up for each other and for the values we share?   "I know that those gathered here believe in the importance of freedom, compassion, and respect. But we must do more than talk about those values. We must make them the foundation of the communities we build, day in and day out, even when it’s not easy. Religious freedom is one of the cornerstones of our democracy. We must lead by example and show the world that here, in our community, people are welcome, no matter their race or their religion. That’s what it means to be an American.”

Sharon Severini had it all figured out: after undergoing a laryngectomy surgery, which requires a neck stoma in order to breathe, as long as she found a third party supplier to purchase her durable medical goods, Medicaid would reimburse her for the costs of her supplies. When she struggled to find a supplier in Connecticut, Sharon was not sure where to turn. Fortunately, Sharon called my office and we were able to connect her with the people and resources she needed to take care of herself. Now, she has over a month’s supply of medical goods. I am glad we were able to help Sharon, and that she will continue to receive the care she deserves.

Russia’s interference in the electoral process is a threat to American democracy. By deliberately undermining the credibility of our free press, as well as purposefully misleading voters with dishonest information, Russia has wronged the American people. The American people deserve to know to the fullest extent Russia’s activities in our electoral process, and who from within the United States may have enabled this to happen.  And we must take steps to protect ourselves in the future from such interference in our elections by a hostile foreign power.

Defunding health care providers like Planned Parenthood is a partisan attack on both men and women who depend on the clinic for vital reproductive health services. For many, the closure of Planned Parenthood locations in places like Torrington means losing a place that provides comprehensive health services, such as STD and HIV testing and treatment, reproductive planning, and screenings for breast and cervical cancer. Effectively cutting off the access to care for those who most need it is incomprehensible to me.

“This bill is a gateway to a much bigger and better tomorrow,” said Crowley. “It seems too good to be true, but it works. My investments are already paying for themselves. One of my buildings needed a roof, so I thought why not get the solar roof?”   Well said, Ken.

Balancing the needs of our farmers and small businesses is important to encouraging farmers like Jonathan of Deeply Rooted Farms to continue expanding their opportunities. By working directly with farmers, we can pass legislation that helps protect food and land while allowing farmers to run their business in the way they know best.

Very proud to serve on the House Veterans Affairs Committee, where we're working on major, bipartisan reforms to support our nation's veterans and military families. Just last week, the Committee Chairman, Dr. Phil Roe (R-TN), joined me for a telephone town hall discussion with my constituents.  That sight - a Republican and a Democrat coming together to speak candidly with the American people about important issues - shouldn't be so rare. That's what every day in Congress should look like.

This is good news. CT residents overwhelmingly opposed the proposed coastal high-speed rail route, and I'm glad federal officials listened. I will continue to push for a high-speed route through central Connecticut, which would be transformative for local economies throughout our district.

Here we go again. The American people are tired of watching congressional Republicans treat their access to affordable health care like a political football. We need a bipartisan approach focused on actually improving health care, not on prolonging this cruel political crusade.

I had never presented 15 military medals to a single person before, but I am glad I was able to do so for Darnell. He answered the call to defend our country during some of the most trying of times, and for 10 years devoted his life to the U.S. Army. He is truly an American hero, and I cannot thank him enough for his service to our country.

Last night we passed the biggest expansion of veterans' education benefits in a decade through the House. These benefits can be life-changing for veterans and their families. One of the most important improvements in our bill is this: From now on, Purple Heart recipients -- heroes who bled for this country -- will be eligible for education benefits regardless of how long they served.  I shared with my colleagues the story of a young Purple Heart recipient from Cheshire who went to school with my son Thomas, and who at 19 lost his left leg when he was hit by an IED. I hope you'll take a moment to listen.

The Senate will now begin voting whether to replace the Affordable Care Act with... no one knows, not even the Senators who voted Yes. This secrecy and slap-dash horsetrading will not serve the American people.  To my Republican colleagues: Drop the secrecy. Start over with an open and transparent process. Put country before party.

This shouldn't slide under the radar today: The House just voted 419-3 to pass significant economic sanctions on Russia, Iran, and North Korea. This sanctions package will strengthen our nation's security against three nations that have repeatedly threatened our interests. And it will send a unified message that the United States will not tolerate assaults on our people, our allies, or our democracy.

An astounding headline: "Senate Republicans hope their own Obamacare repeal won't become law." Friends, if you don't want it to become law then don't vote for it!  This process truly couldn't get more absurd. We all know "Skinny Repeal" would be a disaster. 16 million more people uninsured next year, skyrocketing premiums, an unraveling health care system. So let's drop the antics and have a real bipartisan discussion about how to improve health care. It's what the country wants, and what it deserves.

Mitch McConnell unveiled a new care bill at 9:53 p.m. A vote is planned on it within the next few *hours.*  Virtually everyone - Republicans, Democrats, health care experts - agrees the bill would destabilize the health care system and send premiums skyrocketing. Yet the Senate GOP seems determined to pass it - provided the House pledges not to.  This secretive, outlandish process reached new heights tonight. Let's not forget that millions of Americans' access to affordable health care hangs in the balance. The only responsible course is to vote No and start over with an approach focused on solving problems, not on scoring a political win at any cost.
The time has long passed for assigning blame. It's time to start fixing and healing – both health care and Congress.

This got completely buried in last week's roller coaster of a news cycle, but Rep. John Larson and I passed an amendment to improve support for innovators like Fuel Cell Energy that create good-paying, sustainable jobs in Connecticut and across the country.  I also introduced a bipartisan amendment to improve funding for advanced American manufacturing programs, to ensure that we can compete with nations like China and India when it comes to the latest technological innovations. This amendment was very narrowly defeated (203-224), but the vote was so close that I'll keep looking for ways to get it passed.

I'm part of a group of Democrats and Republicans committed to fixing the problems in our health care system in a bipartisan way. Today we unveiled a set of ideas that we believe are worth exploring - ideas to reduce premiums, stabilize the marketplace, and give Americans more and better options for care.  I hope our proposal can be the starting point for the kind of progress the American people deserve. The kind of progress that comes through honesty and transparency. The kind of progress that comes when we commit to solving problems instead of scoring political points.

Is bipartisan progress on health care possible? Yes, absolutely - but we need to stop obsessing over political "winners" and "losers" and start talking about how to fix things. Last night I joined Joy Reid on The Rachel Maddow Show to discuss the bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus and the ideas our group has put forward for fixing the Affordable Care Act.
